On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 23:57, Patrick Wong wrote:
> I'm not familiar with Lua, so I don't really know if
> the "common man," so to speak, would have an easy time
> scripting classes. I personally prefer Python as a
> scripting language, but then again, a Python
> interpreter would probably make Openglad a *little*
> bit bigger than it needs to be. However, I'll just say
> this: letting people script their own classes means
> nothing if they can't figure out how to do it. But I
> guess you already knew that, and I'm just trying to
> show that someone besides DPH cares about Gladiator.

Hmm... Well, knowing less about Python than I should for making
intelligent comments about it, Lua looks to me a bit easier for someone
to comprehend than Python. If all goes well, an example special in Lua
would be something like this:

-- comment describing kill_foe
function kill_foe
	myfoe = get_closest_foe(me);
	play_sound("superboom.ogg");
	kill(foe);
end

Now, somewhere there would be a table with the names of the specials,
although we could do something like assume that the function name, with
all _'s turned to spaces and the first letter of each word capitalized
is what the person wants as the name.

The actual class would be a bit harder, probably, but might go something
like this:

-- this is a soldier class
soldier =
{
	-- initial stats
	init_hp = 90,
	init_mp = 30,
	init_str = 12,
	init_dex = 7,
	init_suchandsuch = blahblahblah,

	-- stat costs
	cost_str = 4,
	cost_dex = 7,
	cost_suchandsuch = bleh,

	-- AI settings
	escape_special = charge, -- this charge function would be
				 -- defined in the specials
	death_special = kill_foe,
	run_range = 0,

	-- specials
	special =
	{
		charge,
		boomerang,
		blah,
		bleh
	},

	alt_special =
	{
		disarm
	}
}

Sorry if that was long. I'm thinking out loud here. Anyways, that's the
basic idea. It could be prettied up more, but that's the basic idea. All
the curly brackets might scare people off, but if one pads the file with
enough comments and maybe goes easy on the tabs (lua doesn't care much
about whitespaces), it could be made to look quite inviting. Advanced
coders can utilize a lot more of lua, like anonymous functions and all
that fun stuff. An excellent (although unfinished) book on Lua is
available at http://www.inf.puc-rio.br/~roberto/luabook1.pdf and takes
you through everything you need to know to write cool and complex lua
programs.

The other reason for using Lua is that its really really small,
rediculously easy to embed, fully extendable with C/C++ functions, and
compiles on every platform that has a standards-compliant C or C++
compiler. Python might be all that too, though (except small, but that's
forgivable).
